title: Consumer Sentiment Rose at End of September
text:
By Likhitha Butchireddygari

WASHINGTON--A measure of U.S. household sentiment increased at the end of September amid a pickup in the housing market and continued U.S. growth.

--The University of Michigan said Friday its final index of September consumer sentiment was 93.2, up from the preliminary September reading of 92. Economists surveyed by The Wall Street Journal expected sentiment to stay at 92 at the end of September.

--The survey's measure of future expectations also rose to 83.4, up from 82.4 earlier in the month.

--The slight increase in sentiment was attributed to favorable income trends and positive finances, which have held trade policy concerns in check, said Richard Curtin, the survey's chief economist. "Despite the high levels of confidence, consumers have also expressed rising levels of economic uncertainty. Some of these concerns are rooted in partisanship, some due to conditions in the global economy (Brexit, Iran, Saudi Arabia, China), and some are tied to domestic economic policies," Mr. Curtin said.

Write to Likhitha Butchireddygari at likhitha.butchireddygari@wsj.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

September 27, 2019 10:25 ET (14:25 GMT)
